facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 104 of 1954 and 169 of 1956 are before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 104 of 1954 and 169 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 13, 1950, of the Madras High Court in A. S. No. 484 of 1947 arising out of the judgment and decree dated December 21, 1946, of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Devakottai in Original Suit No. 156 of 1944 and Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 17, 1952 and October 24, 1952, of the Madras High Court in A.S. No. 243 of 1947 arising out of the judgment and decree dated December 21, in Original Suit No. 164 of the Subordinate Judge, Devakottai in Original Suit No. 164.

facts.text: Appeal No. 104 of 1954 by special leave under Art. 136 from Madras High Court judgment dated November 13, 1950 in A.S. No. 484 of 1947 from Subordinate Judge Devakottai O.S. No. 156 of 1944 dated December 21, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 13, 1950, of the Madras High Court in A. S. No. 484 of 1947 arising out of the judgment and decree dated December 21, 1946, of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Devakottai in Original Suit No. 156 of 1944 and Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 17, 1952 and October 24, 1952, of the Madras High Court in A.S. Aiyangar, for the appellants in C.A. No. 104 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal No. 169 of 1956 by certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) from Madras High Court judgments dated September 17, 1952 and October 24, 1952 in A.S. No. 243 of 1947 from Subordinate Judge Devakottai O.S. No. 164 dated December 21, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 17, 1952 and October 24, 1952, of the Madras High Court in A.S. No. 243 of 1947 arising out of the judgment and decree dated December 21, in Original Suit No. 164 of the Subordinate Judge, Devakottai in Original Suit No. 164. V. Vishwanatha Sastri and M. S. K. Aiyangar, for the appellants in C.A. No. 104 of 1954. V. Vishwanatha Sastri and U. S. K. Sastri, for the appellants in C.A. No. 169 of 1956. S. Krishnaswamy Iyengar and R. Ganapathy Iyer, for respondent No. 1  in both the appeals . 1957. May 24.

facts.text: Periakaruppan Chettiar owned and possessed considerable properties.

anchor.surface_text: The parties to the litigation are Nattukottai Chetties, a wealthy banking companymunity in South India who, at the time, were having large banking transactions in Burma and other places in South-East Asia. One AL. PR. Periakaruppan Chettiar  hereinafter referred to as Periakaruppa  owned and possessed companysiderable properties.

facts.text: Periakaruppan Chettiar adopted AL. PR. Alagappa Chettiar (Alaska) in or about 1914.

anchor.surface_text: He adopted one AL. PR. Alaska Chettiar  hereinafter, referred to as Alaska  in or about the year 1914. there arose acute differences between them from about the year 1924 owing to the alleged wasteful habits of Alagappa who ran into debts.

facts.text: Acute differences between Periakaruppan and Alagappa from about 1924 due to Alagappa's wasteful habits and debts.

anchor.surface_text: there arose acute differences between them from about the year 1924 owing to the alleged wasteful habits of Alagappa who ran into debts. This led to criminal companyplaints between them, each against the other, in 1926.  See Exs. P-5 and D-12 .

facts.text: Criminal complaints between Periakaruppan and Alagappa in 1926 (Exs. P-5 and D-12).

anchor.surface_text: This led to criminal companyplaints between them, each against the other, in 1926.  See Exs. P-5 and D-12 . One of Alagappas creditors obtained a decree against him and attached Alagappas half share in the family residential house including the site on which it was situated.

facts.text: One of Alagappa's creditors obtained decree and attached Alagappa's half share in family residential house.

anchor.surface_text: One of Alagappas creditors obtained a decree against him and attached Alagappas half share in the family residential house including the site on which it was situated. This resulted in a regular suit in which the question at issue was whether the site was ancestral site and whether the super-structure was companystructed out of the ancestral funds.

facts.text: Madras High Court judgment dated November 19, 1926: site ancestral, superstructure Periakaruppan's self-acquisition (Periakarappan Arunachalam, 1926 I.L.R. 50 Mad. 582).

anchor.surface_text: The litigation went up to the High Court and the High Court accepted the companytention of Periakaruppa and made a declaration that the site was ancestral and that the super-structure was the self- acquisition of Periakaruppa. The judgment of the High Court was dated November 19, 1926, and is reported in Periakarappan Arunachalam  1 .

facts.text: During pendency of High Court litigation, Alagappa filed suit O.S. No. 114 of 1926 on September 9, 1926, on behalf of himself and minor son junior Periakaruppan vs Periakaruppan and second adopted son Ranganathan.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of this litigation in the High Court the adopted son Alagappa filed a suit on September 9, 1926, on behalf of himself and his minor son by name AL. PR. AL. Periakaruppan Chettiar  hereinafter, for distinction, referred to as junior Periakaruppa  represented by his mother and next friend by name Mutbayi Act.

facts.text: Periakaruppan purported to adopt second son Ranganathan on June 27, 1926, claiming Nattukottai Chetti custom allows second adoption.

anchor.surface_text: It has to be mentioned that in or about June 27, 1926, Periakaruppa purported to make a second adoption of a young boy by name AL. PR. Ranganathan Chettiar  hereinafter referred to as Ranganatha  on the footing that such an adoption was permitted by special custom in Nattukottai Chetti families.

facts.text: O.S. No. 114 of 1926 compromised by Rajinama on August 15, 1927: Alagappa and junior got Rs.75,000 each, Muthayi Rs.14,000; properties admitted self-acquired; plaintiffs no rights; vacate house; withdraw Privy Council appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Before the suit proceeded to the stage of issues and trial, the dispute between the parties was companypromised by a Rajinama brought about by four Panchayatdars... As a result, the companypromise was accepted by the companyrt on August 15, 1927, and the suit was dismissed in terms thereof on the same date.

facts.text: Periakaruppan executed will on April 4, 1929; genuineness not in question.

anchor.surface_text: About a year and a half later Periakaruppa executed a will on April 4, 1929. The genuineness and due execution thereof are number in question. But the effect of that will is also one of the main points in dispute.

facts.text: Periakaruppan died on July 14, 1929; wife Lakshmi Achi died March 11, 1930.

anchor.surface_text: Periakaruppa died about three months later i.e. on July 14, 1929, and his wife Lakshmi Achi died within a year thereof on March 11, 1930.

facts.text: Will gave residue to wife for life, then to Ranganathan; Ranganatha in possession since 1930 till 1944.

anchor.surface_text: By the will, broadly speaking, Periakaruppa made arrangements for certain religious gifts and  1   1926  I.L.R. 50 Mad. 582. charities and made arrangements for the management thereof and gave the residue of the property to his wife Lakshmi Achi for her life and thereafter to his second adopted son Ranganatha.

facts.text: Junior Periakaruppan attained majority December 1943, filed O.S. 156/1944 and O.S. 164/1944 on November 11, 1944 in Subordinate Judge Devakottai.

anchor.surface_text: Alagappas son junior Periakaruppa attained majority in December, 1943, and filed two suits on November 11, 1944, in the Subordinate Judges Court of Devakottai, one numbered as S. 156 of 1944 and the other as O.S. 160 of 1944.

facts.text: O.S. 156/1944 (trust suit): Rs.75,000 under Rajinama constituted trust, appropriated by Chockalingam; Periakaruppan co-trustee liable.

anchor.surface_text: O.S. No. 156 of 1944 was on the footing that Rs. 75,000 which was given to him under the above mentioned Rajinama of the year 1927, was, under the terms thereof companystituted a trust for his benefit during his minority under the trusteeship of Periakaruppa himself and another person A. P. S. Chockalingam Chettiar of Athangudi...

facts.text: O.S. 164/1944 (succession suit): Recover properties from Ranganatha; adoption invalid, will ineffective; devolves on Alagappa and junior.

anchor.surface_text: The second suit O.S. No. 164 of 1944 was a suit to recover the entire properties of Periakaruppa in the possession of Ranganatha for himself and his father Alagappa who was made the first defendant in the suit, on the ground that Ranganathas adoption was invalid, that the will of Periakaruppa was ineffective and that the properties devolved on himself and his father Alagappa.

facts.text: Both lower courts found Ranganatha's adoption invalid (not disputed in Supreme Court).

anchor.surface_text: So far as the adoption of Ranganatha was companycerned both the companyrts below, while holding that the adoption as a fact was proved, have found against existence of the custom pleaded as to its validity and hence companycurrently found the adoption to be invalid. That companyclusion is numberlonger in dispute in this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court held will effective, Ranganatha takes as persona designata; succession suit dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, companye to a clear companyclusion that Ranganatha obtained title to the properties of Periakaruppa under the will. This is in accord with the companyduct of Alagappa for over 14 years after the death of Periakaruppa and his wife, in keeping silent and allowing Ranganatha to enjoy the. properties without laying any claim to the property on the ground of the invalidity of the will and the invalidity of the adoption.

facts.text: Rajinama terms: Rs.75,000 for junior Periakaruppan to be invested in Chetti houses to order of Periakaruppan and Chockalingam; they in management.

anchor.surface_text: The Sridhanam amount of Rs. 14,000 of Muthayi Achi., mother of the second plaintiff, and the second plaintiffs amount of Rs. 75,000 out of the aforesaid amount of Rs. 1,50,000 under the hundis, shall be invested in Chetti houses in the name of the second plaintiff to the order of Periakaruppan Chettiar, the first defendant, and to the order of A.P.S. Chockalingam Chettiar of Athangudi...

facts.text: Supreme Court held no trust created; Periakaruppan not trustee for Rs.75,000.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the respondent, junior Periakaruppa, urges that for this purpose it is the Rajinama alone that has to be looked into but number the terms of the hundi. We are unable to agree with this companytention.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent, junior Periakaruppa, urges that for this purpose it is the Rajinama alone that has to be looked into but not the terms of the hundi. We are unable to agree with this contention.

holdings.text: The adoption of Ranganatha is invalid as the custom permitting second adoption among Nattukottai Chettis was not proved.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the adoption of Ranganatha was concerned both the courts below, while holding that the adoption as a fact was proved, have found against existence of the custom pleaded as to its validity and hence concurrently found the adoption to be invalid. That conclusion is no longer in dispute in this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings of lower courts on failure to prove custom accepted and not disputed before Supreme Court.

holdings.text: The will of Periakaruppa effectively conveys title to the residue of his properties to Ranganatha as persona designata notwithstanding the invalidity of the adoption.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, come to a clear conclusion that Ranganatha obtained title to the properties of Periakaruppa under the will. This is in accord with the conduct of Alagappa for over 14 years after the death of Periakaruppa and his wife,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction of will clauses shows disposition to Ranganatha personally based on language, family history excluding Alagappa, testator's intent, and Privy Council precedents distinguishing status description from conditional gift.

holdings.text: The Rajinama and hundi do not constitute Periakaruppa a trustee for the Rs.75,000 payable to junior Periakaruppa.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent, junior Periakaruppa, urges that for this purpose it is the Rajinama alone that has to be looked into but not the terms of the hundi. We are unable to agree with this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rajinama and hundi read integrally; terms do not impose trusteeship on Periakaruppa; contemporaneous conduct shows Chockalingam handled investments with guardians' authority, Periakaruppa uninvolved.

holdings.text: A deposit receipt for investment in Chetti firms is not a negotiable instrument under the Negotiable Instruments Act, and 'to the order of' does not confer legal ownership or withdrawal control as in hundis.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes hundi (negotiable) from subsequent deposit receipt (not negotiable); NI Act sections apply to hundi collection but not deposit; no proof of control via 'order'.

holdings.text: The phrase 'mel parthu' (over-seeing/supervision) in Rajinama does not imply management or operational control constituting trusteeship.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Tamil phrase interpreted as supervision, not management/control; contextual reading with investment terms shows no trustee duty.

anchor.surface_text: is reported in Periakarappan Arunachalam 1 . During the pendency of this litigation in the High Court the adopted son Alagappa filed a suit on September 9, 1926, on behalf of himself and his minor son by name AL. PR. AL. Periakaruppan Chettiar

This compromise was certified to be for the benefit of the minor plaintiff concerned, as also of the minor defendant Ranganatha and was accepted by the Subordinate Judge before whom the compromise petition was filed.

precedents.citation: Nidhoomoni Debya v. Saroda Pershad Mookerjee 1

anchor.surface_text: of the Privy Council cited before us, viz., Nidhoomoni Debya v. Saroda Pershad Mookerjee 1  and Fanindra Deb Raikat v. Rajeshwar Das 2  . As pointed out in the first case the question in all such cases is whether the gift of the property by the testator to a person who is referred to as having been adopted is one which is dependent on whether all the requisites of a valid adoption have been complied with or whether it is to a designated person notwithstanding that it was desired and expected that the requisites for a valid adoption were complied with.

precedents.case_name: Nidhoomoni Debya v. Saroda Pershad Mookerjee
precedents.cited_proposition: whether gift to person referred to as adopted depends on valid adoption or to designated person notwithstanding
precedents.cited_holding: the question in all such cases is whether the gift ... is dependent on whether all the requisites of a valid adoption have been complied with or whether it is to a designated person notwithstanding that it was desired and expected that the requisites for a valid adoption were complied with

precedents.citation: Fanindra Deb Raikat v. Rajeshwar Das 2

anchor.surface_text: Nidhoomoni Debya v. Saroda Pershad Mookerjee 1  and Fanindra Deb Raikat v. Rajeshwar Das 2  . As pointed out in the first case the question in all such cases is whether the gift of the property by the testator to a person who is referred to as having been adopted is one which is dependent on whether all the requisites of a valid adoption have been complied with or whether it is to a designated person notwithstanding that it was desired and expected that the requisites for a valid adoption were complied with. As pointed out by their Lordships in the second case the distinction between what is description only and what is the reason or motive of a gift or bequest may often be very fine, but it is a distinction which must be drawn from a consideration of the language and the surrounding circumstances.

precedents.case_name: Fanindra Deb Raikat v. Rajeshwar Das
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between description only and reason or motive of gift from language and circumstances
precedents.cited_holding: the distinction between what is description only and what is the reason or motive of a gift or bequest may often be very fine, but it is a distinction which must be drawn from a consideration of the language and the surrounding circumstances

anchor.surface_text: the Privy Council in Arunachalam v. Vairavan 1  and in Muthuraman v. Periannan 2 . In view of these decisions and the fact to which our attention has been drawn that there is no pleading in this case as to the meaning of the word maral or that the word order in the context of this case has been used in the sense

precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of the word maral must depend on the proof in each particular case of usage of that word by the Nattukottai Chetti firms

anchor.surface_text: Arunachalam v. Vairavan 1  and in Muthuraman v. Periannan 2 . In view of these decisions and the fact to which our attention has been drawn that there is no pleading in this case as to the meaning of the word maral or that the word order in the context of this case has been used in the sense A.I.R. 1929 P.C. 254, 256. 2 A.I.R, 1934 Mad. 621, 622. of maral, we are not prepared to uphold the contention that the word order in this case can be given the meaning which is attributed to the word maral in some of the cases which have been cited to us for the appellant.

precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of the word maral must depend on the proof in each particular case of usage of that word by the Nattukottai Chetti firms

precedents.citation: Krishnashet bin Ganshet Shetye v. Hari Valjibhatye 1

anchor.surface_text: under the Negotiable Instruments Act. He urges that in the case of a negotiable instrument the person who is indicated as the orderer  if that word may be used in this context  is the holder thereof and is the person who is entitled to receive the amount thereunder and to give a discharge in respect thereof and that, therefore, he is virtually the legal owner thereof. If, as held in Krishnashet bin Ganshet Shetye v. Hari Valjibhatye 1 , the Negotiable Instruments Act,  in the absence of any local usage to the contrary  applies to hundis, what is urged above may well be applicable to the money of the original hundi for Rs. 75,000 drawn on Muthiah Chetti and specifically payable on demand to the order of the three persons, Alagappa, Muthayi Achi and Chockalingam.

precedents.case_name: Krishnashet bin Ganshet Shetye v. Hari Valjibhatye
precedents.cited_proposition: Negotiable Instruments Act applies to hundis in absence of local usage to contrary

anchor.surface_text: under s. 13 of the Negotiable Instruments Act. There is no authority for showing that such a deposit receipt is a 1 1895 I.L.R. 20 Bom. 488. document to which the provisions of Negotiable Instruments Act as to the use of the word order and the legal implications thereof would be applicable. On the other hand there appears to, be authority to the contrary. See Sethna v. Hemmingway 1  and In re Travancore National and Quilon Bank Ltd. 1 .

precedents.cited_proposition: deposit receipt is not a negotiable instrument

precedents.citation: In re Travancore National and Quilon Bank Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: to the contrary. See Sethna v. Hemmingway 1  and In re Travancore National and Quilon Bank Ltd. 1 . Both these cases indicate that a deposit receipt is not a negotiable instrument. It is true that in the language of the hundi, at both places, i.e.,  1  where the hundi is to be cashed, and  2  at the place where the cash so collected is to be invested, the same word order is used with reference to different sets of persons.

precedents.case_name: In re Travancore National and Quilon Bank Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: deposit receipt is not a negotiable instrument

anchor.surface_text: So far as the adoption of Ranganatha was concerned both the courts below, while holding that the adoption as a fact was proved, have found against existence of the custom pleaded as to its validity and hence concurrently found the adoption to be invalid. That conclusion is no longer in dispute in this Court.
This appeal, i.e., Civil Appeal No. 169 of 1956, is accordingly allowed with costs throughout and the plaintiffs suit dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent, junior Periakaruppa, urges that for this purpose it is the Rajinama alone that has to be looked into but not the terms of the hundi. We are unable to agree with this contention.
